body: Would you mind sorting these in alphabetical order?
Thanks for the heads-up. I've made the edits.

Note that for the new example the command is long and using a intermediary file (`path/to/pubkey.gpg`) because the `--keyring` option in `gpgv` does not work with named pipes.

```
gpg --dearmor {{[-o|--output]}} {{path/to/pubkey.gpg}} < {{path/to/pubkey.txt}} && gpgv --keyring {{path/to/pubkey.gpg}} {{path/to/signature.asc}} {{path/to/data_file}}
```

Would you mind opening a "Lets document" issue on the issue tracker so that we can track the documentation progress?

> Would you mind opening a "Lets document" issue on the issue tracker so that we can track the documentation progress?

I have opened "Lets document: koji" issue.  https://github.com/tldr-pages/tldr/issues/19268

btrfs-device is something I'm on the fence about: https://github.com/tldr-pages/tldr/blob/npm-pkg/pages/linux/btrfs-device.md

`sudo btrfs {{[d|device]}} {{[rem|remove]}} {{path/to/device1|device_id1 path/to/device2|device_id2 ...}}`

https://github.com/tldr-pages/tldr/blob/npm-pkg/pages/common/komac.md

`komac update {{Package.Identifier}} {{[-v|--version]}} {{1.2.3}} {{[-u|--urls]}} {{https://example.com/app.exe https://example.com/app.msi ...}} {{[-s|--submit]}}`

https://github.com/tldr-pages/tldr/blob/npm-pkg/pages/common/xml-validate.md

`xml {{[val|validate]}} {{[-d|--dtd]}} {{path/to/schema.dtd}} {{path/to/input1.xml|URI1 path/to/input2.xml|URI2 ...}}`

https://github.com/tldr-pages/tldr/blob/npm-pkg/pages/common/ocrmypdf.md

`ocrmypdf --title "{{title}}" --author "{{author}}" --subject "{{subject}}" --keywords "{{keyword; key phrase; ...}}" {{path/to/input.pdf}} {{path/to/output.pdf}}`

https://github.com/tldr-pages/tldr/blob/npm-pkg/pages/common/mpg321.md

`mpg321 {{[-Z|--random]}} {{path/to/file_a|URL path/to/file_b|URL ...}}`

https://github.com/tldr-pages/tldr/blob/npm-pkg/pages/common/ifne.md

`ifne -n {{command options ...}}`

https://github.com/tldr-pages/tldr/blob/npm-pkg/pages/common/clementine.md

`clementine {{[-c|--create]}} {{url1 url2 ...|path/to/music1.ext path/to/music2.ext ...}}`

https://github.com/tldr-pages/tldr/blob/npm-pkg/pages/common/ar.md

`ar r {{path/to/file.deb}} {{path/to/debian-binary path/to/control.tar.gz path/to/data.tar.xz ...}}`

Is hwloc-ls just an alias for lstopo? https://manned.org/hwloc-ls

So it seems 
```
$ file /bin/hwloc-ls
/bin/hwloc-ls: symbolic link to lstopo-no-graphics
```

Create a page named `lstopo-no-graphics.md` and fill it with the contents of this file. Then create an [alias page](https://github.com/tldr-pages/tldr/blob/main/contributing-guides/style-guide.md#aliases) out of this.

Arch official repos do not contain the official ookla speedtest. Only `speedtest-cli`

Hello! I've noticed something unusual when checking this PR at commit
[`508956fe2a45f76623be67db1679404893361747`](https://github.com/tldr-pages/tldr/commit/508956fe2a45f76623be67db1679404893361747):

- The page `pages.zh/windows/wget.md` is outdated, based on the command contents itself, compared to the English page.

Is this intended? If so, just ignore this comment. Otherwise, please double-check the commits.

```
$ grep -r "{{command}}" | wc -l
528
$ grep -r "{{program}}" | wc -l
39
```
However I sort of agree that in this case program makes more sense. You're essentially passing the data to the program while the command is just the syntax for the program. Does anyone have any differing opinions?

> ```
> $ grep -r "{{command}}" | wc -l
> 528
> $ grep -r "{{program}}" | wc -l
> 39
> ```
> 
> However I sort of agree that in this case program makes more sense. You're essentially passing the data to the program while the command is just the syntax for the program. Does anyone have any differing opinions?

I think both would work fine here in English, but translating command is easier/more direct than program in most languages, since "program" might mean a computer program or an event. But in case of command it just has a singular meaning.

This is an interesting idea, but symlinks on Windows are problematic for cross-platform projects.
Historically, creating them required admin rights. While Developer Mode in modern Windows allows it, we can't assume users have it enabled. By default, Git on Windows often checks out symlinks as small text files containing the target path, which would break the functionality.

Hi @sapbotgit, thank you for this contribution!
More Information Link: The current link points to the ZDoom wiki. I think a more general link like https://doomwiki.org/wiki/Source_port_parameters would be more useful for users of any source port.

> Hi @sapbotgit, thank you for this contribution! More Information Link: The current link points to the ZDoom wiki. I think a more general link like https://doomwiki.org/wiki/Source_port_parameters would be more useful for users of any source port.

Yeah, you right

I've been looking into the {{sourceport}} placeholder. Am I correct in understanding that the arguments for multiplayer or modding can differ significantly between various source ports (like GZDoom vs. Zandronum)?

> I've been looking into the {{sourceport}} placeholder. Am I correct in understanding that the arguments for multiplayer or modding can differ significantly between various source ports (like GZDoom vs. Zandronum)?

Almost no. Even Zandronum supports `-host`, `-join`.

> Please run `scripts/set-more-info-link.py -Sl ru` to fix the tldr-bot issue. Make sure to only commit the `doom`-page.

It doesn't changed doom
```
sapbot@sapbot-PC:~/tldr$ python3 scripts/set-more-info-link.py -Sl ru
pages.ru/linux/ip-route-list.md link added
```

> Please run `scripts/set-more-info-link.py -Sl ru` to fix the tldr-bot issue. Make sure to only commit the `doom`-page.

Yeah, and the commit that bot is referenced, is only update of en, RU update has been in other commit.

> > I've been looking into the {{sourceport}} placeholder. Am I correct in understanding that the arguments for multiplayer or modding can differ significantly between various source ports (like GZDoom vs. Zandronum)?
> 
> Almost no. Even Zandronum supports `-host`, `-join`.

That leads to a more specific point I wanted to discuss.
To follow up, if we were to use a specific binary like `{{path/to/zandronum-server}}` instead of the generic `{{sourceport}}`, would all the examples on the page still work as written?
I'm bringing this up because this PR is linked to the "Let's document: Headless game servers" issue (#17125). My understanding is that Zandronum is a perfect fit for this, since `zandronum-server` is a true headless binary (no graphics, no client). On the other hand, ports like GZDoom are peer-to-peer, where the host is also a player rendering the game.

I was thinking the same. If some user is a first timer to doom server hosting, the word "sourceport" might mean nothing to them. I agree with Ivan that the best solution is likely to include `zandronum-server` as the binary name if it's the most popular sourceport and add to the header "> `zandronum-server` can be replaced with any alternative sourceport"

> > > I've been looking into the {{sourceport}} placeholder. Am I correct in understanding that the arguments for multiplayer or modding can differ significantly between various source ports (like GZDoom vs. Zandronum)?
> > 
> > 
> > Almost no. Even Zandronum supports `-host`, `-join`.
> 
> That leads to a more specific point I wanted to discuss. My understanding is that Zandronum is a perfect fit for this, since `zandronum-server` is a true headless binary (no graphics, no client). On the other hand, ports like GZDoom are peer-to-peer, where the host is also a player rendering the game.

`zandronum-server` has custom cli parameters, and i think more wider and better definition will be `{{path/to/doom}}`. (Answer/react to me if agree)
I don't think the custom parameters matter if we don't document them.
I thinked something about currently documentating standart CLI parameters, then documenting in it's own page zandronum's.
Might be useful. But lets get this page done first.

> Might be useful. But lets get this page done first.

So, what, `{{path/to/doom}}`? Or you got a better idea?
Just `{{zandronum-server}}`. It's a sourceport so it's available in package managers.

> Just `{{zandronum-server}}`. It's a sourceport so it's available in package managers.

But what about others? Maybe add in description note that you can replace `{{zandronum-server}}` with your port? There are SOOO much other ports.
Yeah, that was my original idea as well. Add something like ``> `zandronum-server` can be replaced with any sourceport.``

> > `zandronum-server` can be replaced with any sourceport.

One question, zandronum-server on hosting, just zandronum on joining or what?
And I believe using `zandronum-server` allows us to keep the page name as `doom`, as this would align with the guidelines in issue #17125. This way, we also avoid creating extra pages.

Let's simplify and stick to the goal of the "Headless game servers" issue (#17125).
Here is the plan:
1. Focus only on the server-related commands.
2. Replace all instances of {{sourceport}} with {{path/to/zandronum-server}}.
